questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lewy body dementia


Lewy body dementia is a progressive and irreversible neurodegenerative disorder.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. B12 deficiency: Reversible with supplementation.
 

Option B. Normal pressure hydrocephalus: Reversible with shunting.
 

Option D. Hypothyroidism: Reversible with thyroid hormone replacement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lewy body dementia is not a reversible cause of dementia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a penicillin allergy presents with enterococcal endocarditis. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

Enterococci are gram-positive bacteria, and the first-line treatment for enterococcal infections is typically ampicillin. However, in patients with penicillin allergies, vancomycin is the preferred alternative. Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is effective against gram-positive bacteria, including enterococci. It works by inhibiting cell wall synthesis, leading to bacterial cell death.

 

 

  • Linezolid               
  • Tigecycline (Complicated Skin/Intra-abdominal Infections)
  • Daptomycin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aztreonam: This is a monobactam antibiotic that is primarily effective against gram-negative bacteria particularly in community-acquired pneumonia in ICU patients with a penicillin allergy, Aztreonam is the best choice.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: This is a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic. While effective against some gram-positive bacteria, it is not the preferred choice for enterococcal infections, especially in patients with penicillin allergies due to the risk of cross-reactivity.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: This is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic. It would not be safe to use in a patient with a penicillin allergy due to the risk of a severe allergic reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with penicillin allergies who have enterococcal infections, vancomycin is the preferred and safe alternative for treatment.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has the following laboratory reports. Calculate the anion gap in this patient. Na+: 145 mEq/L, K+ 4 mEq/L Cl: 90 mEq/L HCO3: 20 mEq/L. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 35


The anion gap is calculated using the formula:

 

Anion Gap = Na−(Cl+HCO3)
 

Anion Gap=145−(90+20)=35

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anion gap is calculated as Na - (Cl + HCO3), and a high anion gap may indicate metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is an AR murmur likely to be heard? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ventricular diastole


Aortic regurgitation (AR) murmurs are classic early diastolic murmurs heard during ventricular diastole, when blood flows back into the left ventricle from the aorta.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Ventricular ejection: Associated with systolic murmurs.
 

Option B. Throughout cardiac cycle: Associated with continuous murmurs, like in PDA.
 

Option C. Isovolumetric contraction: Not typically associated with murmurs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic regurgitation murmurs are heard during ventricular diastole

choices.text: Allergic Interstitial Nephritis
Urinary Tract Infection

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with follicular tonsillitis, for which antibiotics were prescribed. In a few days, the child developed flank pain and rash. Peripheral blood demonstrated eosinophilia, and urinalysis showed WBC casts. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allergic Interstitial Nephritis

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), also known as drug-induced interstitial nephritis, is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by medications such as antibiotics (e.g., penicillins). The clinical presentation of AIN typically includes:

 

  • Recent medication use: In this case, antibiotics for follicular tonsillitis.
  • Flank pain and rash: These symptoms often develop a few days after starting the medication.
  • Eosinophilia: Elevated levels of eosinophils in peripheral blood are a hallmark of allergic reactions.
  • Urinalysis findings: Presence of white blood cell (WBC) casts in the urine indicates renal involvement.

 

The combination of these symptoms and laboratory findings strongly suggests allergic interstitial nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyelonephritis: Pyelonephritis is characterized by fever, unilateral flank pain, and urinary symptoms like dysuria. It is usually associated with bacterial infection, not with recent antibiotic use or eosinophilia.

 

Option C. Berger Disease (IgA Nephropathy): IgA nephropathy, or Berger disease, is a glomerulonephritis characterized by hematuria and sometimes proteinuria. It does not typically present with rash, eosinophilia, or WBC casts.

 

Option D. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): A UTI would present with urinary symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency. It can also lead to pyelonephritis, but it does not typically cause eosinophilia or WBC casts in the absence of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis is characterized by recent medication use (such as antibiotics), flank pain, rash, eosinophilia, and WBC casts in urine. It is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by drugs, particularly antibiotics.

questions.text:
What would be seen if the central part of the cord was involved? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs.
  2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs.
  3. Bladder and bowel involvement.
  4. Posterior tract involvement.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

Central cord lesions, such as those seen in conditions like syringomyelia and intramedullary tumors, present with a distinct pattern of neurological deficits due to the anatomical arrangement of the spinal tracts.

 

1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs: This pattern is common in central cord syndromes, where there is damage to the anterior horn cells leading to lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions in the upper limbs. As the condition progresses, upper motor neuron (UMN) signs may appear in the lower limbs due to the involvement of the corticospinal tract.

 

3. Bladder and bowel involvement: Central cord lesions can affect autonomic functions leading to bladder and bowel dysfunction, especially in cases of extensive or progressive lesions like intramedullary tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs: This pattern is not typical for central cord syndromes. Usually, the upper limbs show LMN signs due to the involvement of the anterior horn cells, and the lower limbs show UMN signs.

 

4. Posterior tract involvement: Posterior tracts, which carry fine touch, vibration, and proprioception, are usually spared in central cord syndromes. These tracts are located more dorsally in the spinal cord, away from the central lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Central cord lesions, such as syringomyelia, typically present with LMN signs in the upper limbs, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and can involve bladder and bowel dysfunction, but they do not typically affect the posterior tracts

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibitor?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

PCSK-9 inhibitors are a class of drugs that significantly lower LDL cholesterol levels by inhibiting the protein PCSK-9, which in turn increases the number of LDL receptors available to clear LDL cholesterol from the blood.

 

There are only 2 PCSK-9 inhibitors: Evolocumab and alirocumab. Among the options provided:

 

Evolocumab is a well-known PCSK-9 inhibitor used in modern clinical practice to manage hyperlipidemia, particularly in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or those who are at high risk of cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is an NPC1L1 transport inhibitor, also known as an intestinal cholesterol absorption inhibitor. It reduces blood cholesterol by decreasing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a newer drug that acts as an ANGPTL3 inhibitor. It is specifically approved for use in patients with familial homozygous type 2 hyperlipidemia.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor and an immunosuppressive drug used primarily in organ transplantation and certain types of cancer. It is not related to the treatment of dyslipidemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evolocumab is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to significantly lower LDL cholesterol levels, particularly in high-risk patients.

questions.text: A tall 10-year-old boy presents with Sexual Maturity Rating 5 and hyperpigmentation. His BP is 150/100 mm Hg. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 11β-Hydroxylase deficiency

 

The presentation of a tall 10-year-old boy with a Sexual Maturity Rating (SMR) of 5 and hypertension (BP 150/100 mm Hg) indicates precocious puberty. The SMR of 5 typically signifies full sexual maturity, which is unusual for a 10-year-old and suggests precocious puberty.

 

Hyperpigmentation is likely due to elevated ACTH levels, which can occur in congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The key to the diagnosis is understanding the enzyme deficiencies that lead to CAH and their associated symptoms.

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency leads to increased production of 11-deoxycorticosterone, a mineralocorticoid that causes hypertension due to salt retention. This condition also results in excess androgen production, leading to precocious puberty in boys and virilization in girls.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 21β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This is the most common cause of CAH but is typically associated with salt-wasting, not hypertension. It results in increased androgen production leading to virilization and ambiguous genitalia in females, and precocious puberty in males.

 

Option C. 17β-Hydroxylase deficiency: This deficiency is characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia but does not usually cause hyperpigmentation or precocious puberty. It often results in underdeveloped secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Option D. SCC (side-chain cleavage) deficiency: This enzyme deficiency leads to a severe form of CAH with salt-wasting and adrenal insufficiency but is not typically associated with hypertension or hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

11β-Hydroxylase deficiency in congenital adrenal hyperplasia causes hypertension due to salt retention and precocious puberty due to excess androgen production.

questions.text: In CN III palsy, which of the following is not affected? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abduction

 

Cranial Nerve III (CN III), also known as the oculomotor nerve, innervates several muscles responsible for eye movements and eyelid elevation. These muscles include the superior rectus (elevation), medial rectus (adduction), inferior rectus (depression), and inferior oblique (extorsion and elevation in adduction). It also innervates the levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which is responsible for elevating the eyelid.

 

Abduction is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (CN VI), not the oculomotor nerve. Therefore, abduction is not affected in CN III palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

In CN III palsy, the functions of these muscles are compromised, leading to issues such as:

 

Option A. Elevation: Elevation is affected due to the involvement of the superior rectus muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Option B. Adduction: Adduction is affected due to the involvement of the medial rectus muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Option D. Ptosis: Ptosis occurs due to the involvement of the levator palpebrae superioris muscle innervated by CN III.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In CN III palsy, abduction is not affected because it is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the abducens nerve (CN VI).

questions.text:
Which of the following clinical features can be encountered in Korsakoff psychosis? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Amnesia
  2. Confabulation
  3. Ophthalmoplegia
  4. Peripheral neuropathy
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, 4

 

Korsakoff psychosis, or Korsakoff syndrome, is a chronic neuropsychiatric syndrome resulting from chronic deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1), commonly associated with chronic alcoholism. It is often considered an irreversible condition, unlike its acute counterpart, Wernicke's encephalopathy, which can be treated with thiamine supplementation.

 

Clinical Features of Korsakoff Psychosis:

 

1. Amnesia: Korsakoff syndrome is characterized by severe memory impairment, both anterograde (inability to form new memories) and retrograde (loss of previously formed memories) amnesia. Long-term memory, however, tends to remain relatively intact.

 

2. Confabulation: Patients often exhibit confabulation, where they fabricate stories to fill gaps in their memory. This is not intentional lying but a way to compensate for memory loss.

 

4. Peripheral Neuropathy: Chronic alcoholics often suffer from peripheral neuropathy due to thiamine deficiency and direct neurotoxic effects of alcohol. This neuropathy involves the axons of peripheral nerves and manifests as numbness, tingling, and pain in the extremities.

 

Other Option:

 

Not a Feature of Korsakoff Psychosis:

 

3. Ophthalmoplegia: This is a feature of Wernicke's encephalopathy, which presents acutely with a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion. Ophthalmoplegia refers to paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles. It is reversible with thiamine treatment and is not typically seen in the chronic phase of Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Korsakoff psychosis is characterized by severe memory impairment (amnesia), confabulation, and peripheral neuropathy. It does not include ophthalmoplegia, which is a feature of the acute Wernicke's encephalopathy.

choices.text: Chronic Cocaine use
Subacute progression over 4 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT indicative of underlying serious pathology in headache? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Cocaine use

 

While acute cocaine use can lead to serious complications such as intracranial hemorrhage, chronic cocaine use does not typically present as a headache warning sign for serious pathology unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Age > 50: New onset headache in individuals over 50 years of age is a red flag and suggests the possibility of serious conditions such as giant cell arteritis or intracranial mass lesions.

 

Option B. Temporal tenderness: This is often a sign of temporal arteritis (giant cell arteritis), a serious condition that can lead to blindness if not treated promptly.

 

Option D. Subacute progression over 4 weeks: This indicates a progressive condition such as a brain tumor or increased intracranial pressure, which are serious pathologies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic cocaine use is not typically indicative of a serious underlying pathology in headache unless associated with acute episodes.

 

Headache Symptoms That Suggest a Serious Underlying Disorder

 

  • Sudden-onset headache
  • First severe headache
  • "Worst" headache ever
  • Vomiting that precedes headache
  • Subacute worsening over days or weeks
  • Pain induced by bending, lifting, coughing
  • Pain that disturbs sleep or presents immediately upon awakening
  • Known systemic illness
  • Onset after age 55
  • Fever or unexplained systemic signs
  • Abnormal neurologic examination
  • Pain associated with local tenderness, e.g., region of temporal artery

questions.text: A person comes to the OPD with symptoms of not using his left side and not washing the left side of his body while bathing. On examination he wasn't able to draw the left side of the images. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Right posterior parietal area

 

The symptoms described indicate left-sided hemi-neglect, which is typically due to a lesion in the non-dominant (right) posterior parietal area, responsible for spatial awareness and attention.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Left motor cortex: Would result in right-sided motor deficits.


Option B. Right motor cortex: Would result in left-sided motor deficits but not neglect.


Option C. Left posterior parietal area: Would result in right-sided hemi-neglect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Left-sided neglect is often due to a lesion in the right posterior parietal area.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, having lost her newborn, is producing breast milk, which risks developing into a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which drug can prevent this complication? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

In this scenario, the primary goal is to suppress lactation to prevent milk stasis and subsequent breast abscess formation. Lactation is driven by the hormone prolactin, which is released from the anterior pituitary gland. To suppress milk production, prolactin release must be inhibited.

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine receptor agonist that works by stimulating dopamine receptors, which in turn inhibits prolactin secretion from the anterior pituitary gland. By reducing prolactin levels, cabergoline effectively suppresses lactation, thereby reducing the risk of milk stasis and breast abscess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: This drug is a progesterone receptor antagonist primarily used for medical termination of pregnancy. It does not have a role in suppressing lactation.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: This is an antipsychotic medication that blocks dopamine D2 receptors. Blocking dopamine receptors would actually increase prolactin levels and promote milk production, thus potentially worsening the risk of milk stasis and abscess.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: This drug is a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist and is sometimes used as a galactagogue (to promote milk production). Like chlorpromazine, it would increase prolactin levels and thus is not suitable for preventing lactation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cabergoline, a dopamine receptor agonist, is used to suppress lactation by inhibiting prolactin secretion, thereby preventing complications like milk stasis and breast abscess.

questions.text: Decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism seen with deficiency of: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

Zinc is an essential trace element involved in numerous aspects of cellular metabolism. It plays a vital role in immune function, protein synthesis, wound healing, DNA synthesis, and cell division. Zinc is also crucial for normal growth and development during pregnancy, childhood, and adolescence, and it is necessary for the proper functioning of taste and smell.

 

Features of Zinc Deficiency:

 

  • Decreased Sexual Maturity: Zinc deficiency in children and adolescents can lead to growth retardation and delayed sexual maturation, particularly hypogonadism in males.
  • Hypogonadism: This condition is characterized by the underdevelopment of primary or secondary sexual characteristics, such as the testes in males, leading to delayed or absent puberty.
  • Impaired Immune Function: Zinc deficiency can result in an increased susceptibility to infections.
  • Other Symptoms: Include hair loss, diarrhea, delayed wound healing, and eye and skin lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Deficiency can lead to anemia (microcytic, hypochromic), neutropenia, bone abnormalities, and neurological issues such as peripheral neuropathy and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

 

Option C. Selenium: Deficiency can cause Keshan disease (a type of cardiomyopathy) and Kashin-Beck disease (a type of osteoarthropathy).

 

Option D. Iron: Deficiency is commonly associated with microcytic, hypochromic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency is associated with decreased sexual maturity and hypogonadism, particularly in male children, and is a common nutritional deficiency in developing countries. It is also linked to impaired growth, immune dysfunction, and delayed wound healing.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true about subclinical myocarditis? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Palpitations
  2. Elevated BNP Troponins
  3. Regional wall motion abnormalities in echo
  4. ECG suggestive of myocarditis
  5. Low LVEF in echo
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4,5


Subclinical myocarditis may not present with symptoms like palpitations, but can show:

 

2. Elevated BNP/Troponins: Indicating myocardial injury.

3. Regional wall motion abnormalities: Seen on echocardiography.

4. ECG changes: Suggestive of myocarditis, such as non-specific ST-T changes.

5. Low LVEF: Indicative of impaired left ventricular function.

 

Other Option:
 

1. Palpitations are not a feature of subclinical myocarditis.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Subclinical myocarditis can present with elevated cardiac biomarkers, regional wall motion abnormalities, ECG changes, and reduced LVEF, but not Palpitations, which is common in viral myocarditis.

 

Past common causes of myocarditis: Coxsackie virus types A and B.

 

 

Currently, Most common cause of myocarditis: Parvovirus B19 and HHV6.

questions.text: The absence of loud S1 in mitral stenosis would indicate all of the following, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild mitral stenosis

 

The first heart sound (S1) is produced by the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves at the beginning of systole. In mitral stenosis, the loudness of S1 can vary depending on several factors. A loud S1 is typically associated with the early stages of mitral stenosis when the valve leaflets are still relatively mobile. However, in certain conditions, S1 can become softer.

 

In mild mitral stenosis without significant calcification usually results in a loud S1. This is because the mitral valve leaflets are still relatively mobile and can close forcefully. Therefore, mild mitral stenosis is the correct exception in this context, as it does not typically cause a soft S1.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcified valve: When the mitral valve becomes calcified, it loses its mobility. This results in a softer S1 because the valve leaflets are not able to close rapidly or forcefully.

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation can lead to an increased preload in the left ventricle, which can in turn affect the closure of the mitral valve, making S1 softer. Additionally, mitral regurgitation, which often coexists with mitral stenosis, can also soften S1.

 

Option C. First degree heart block: In first degree AV block, there is a prolonged PR interval. This delayed conduction can lead to a less forceful closure of the mitral valve, resulting in a softer S1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In mitral stenosis, a loud S1 is typically seen in the early stages with mobile valves, while a soft S1 can indicate valve calcification, aortic regurgitation, or first degree heart block. Mild mitral stenosis without calcification usually results in a loud S1

questions.text: A patient recovered from hepatitis B infection. Which of the following curve represents antibodies seen 4 weeks post-recovery? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti HBs

 

After recovery from hepatitis B infection, the patient will have antibodies against the hepatitis B surface antigen (anti-HBS), indicating immunity. The key points related to hepatitis B infection and recovery include:

 

HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Initially present during the acute phase of infection, indicating active infection. It will eventually drop and become negative upon recovery.

 

Anti-HBc (Hepatitis B core antibody): Initially, anti-HBc IgM is positive during the acute phase, which then transitions to anti-HBc IgG as the infection progresses. The total anti-HBc represents both IgM initially and IgG later on.

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen): Indicates active viral replication and high infectivity. It decreases as the virus is cleared.

 

Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): The protective antibody indicating recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection. This antibody appears after the disappearance of HBsAg and is a marker of immunity post-recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anti HBc: Anti-HBc indicates past or current infection with hepatitis B. Initially, IgM anti-HBc is present during the acute infection, and later, IgG anti-HBc persists. However, it does not specifically indicate recovery and immunity.


Option C. HBeAg: HBeAg is a marker of active viral replication and high infectivity. It is present during the active infection phase and decreases as the infection resolves.


Option D. HBsAg: HBsAg indicates active hepatitis B infection. It is present during the acute phase of infection and disappears upon recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-HBs antibodies indicate recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection. This is the only protective antibody that signifies the patient has successfully recovered from the infection and has developed immunity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with left facial weakness. Routine lab workup was normal. What is the next best step in management? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Corticosteroids

 

The presentation of left facial weakness with normal routine lab workup suggests Bell's palsy, an idiopathic condition characterized by sudden onset of unilateral lower motor neuron facial paralysis. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion and is the most common cause of unilateral facial paralysis.

 

Corticosteroids: The first-line treatment for Bell's palsy is corticosteroids. They are most effective when started within 72 hours of symptom onset. Early treatment with corticosteroids can significantly improve the chances of complete recovery. A typical regimen is prednisolone or prednisone.

 

Dosage: Prednisone 60-80 mg per day for 5-7 days, followed by a taper over the next 5-7 days.

 

Note – In the severity grading system, House-Brackmann grading, if the patient has Grade 4 or Grade 5 severity, consider adding antivirals such as acyclovir or valacyclovir.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acyclovir: Although acyclovir or other antiviral agents like valacyclovir are sometimes used, their benefit is less clear. They may be considered in severe cases of Bell's palsy, particularly when there is a suspicion of herpes simplex virus involvement, but they are not the primary treatment.

 

Dosage: Valacyclovir 1 gram TID for 7 days or acyclovir 400 mg five times a day for 7-10 days.

 

Note - Valacyclovir has superior bioavailability, superior efficacy, and lower side effects compared to acyclovir.

 

Option C. Antibiotics: There is no role for antibiotics in the treatment of Bell's palsy as it is not caused by a bacterial infection.

 

Option D. Physiotherapy: While physiotherapy, including facial exercises and eye protection measures, can be supportive, it is not the primary treatment and should be considered an adjunct to corticosteroid therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best initial management for a patient with Bell's palsy is corticosteroid therapy. Early administration within 72 hours of symptom onset greatly enhances the likelihood of complete recovery. Antivirals may be added in severe cases, but they are not the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text:
Erythropoietin is secreted by which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a. Liver
b. Kidney
c. Spleen
d. Heart
questions.solution:
Ans. A) a, b

 

Erythropoietin (EPO) is a hormone responsible for stimulating the production of red blood cells in the bone marrow. The primary source of erythropoietin in the human body is the kidney, which accounts for about 90% of its production. The liver contributes approximately 10% of erythropoietin production.

 

Mechanism of Action:

 

a. Liver: The liver produces erythropoietin mainly during fetal development, and its contribution decreases postnatally, although it continues to produce a small amount in adults.

 

b. Kidney: Erythropoietin is mainly produced by interstitial fibroblast-like cells located in the renal cortex, particularly near the proximal convoluted tubules. The production of EPO in the kidneys is primarily regulated by oxygen levels; hypoxia (low oxygen levels) stimulates its secretion.

 

The spleen and heart are not known sources of erythropoietin production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option c & d: Neither the spleen nor the heart produce erythropoietin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythropoietin is primarily produced by the kidneys (90%) and to a lesser extent by the liver (10%). These organs are the main sources of erythropoietin in the human body, with the kidneys playing a dominant role in its regulation and production in response to hypoxia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with skin thickening muscle weakness and the peripheries becoming pale on exposure to cold. She is positive for ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibodies. Her creatinine kinase is elevated and muscle biopsy shows perifascicular infiltration. What is the antibody associated with this? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibody

 

The patient presents with features of scleroderma and dermatomyositis overlap syndrome. Anti-PM-Scl antibody is associated with this overlap syndrome, tends to produce nucleolar pattern in your ANA immunofluorescence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-U3 RNP: Associated with the diffuse form of scleroderma and are also known as anti-fibrillarin antibodies.
 

Option B. Anti-centromere antibody: Associated with limited scleroderma (CREST syndrome).
 

Option D. Anti-Jo-1 antibody: Associated with antisynthetase syndrome, which predominantly causes interstitial lung disease (ILD), mechanic's hands, myositis, and Raynaud's phenomenon. It is not associated with scleroderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibody is associated with overlap syndromes involving scleroderma and myositis.

questions.text: A decrease in GFR is associated with which of the following? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased Bowman's oncotic pressure

 

If the hydrostatic pressure of the capillaries or the oncotic pressure of the Bowman's capsule decreases, filtration will decrease. If the oncotic pressure in the glomerular capillary increases or if the hydrostatic pressure in the Bowman's capsule increases, GFR will decrease as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is determined by the net filtration pressure, which depends on various pressures within the glomerulus and Bowman's capsule:

 

Option A. Increased Renal Blood Flow: This increases GFR as more blood flow leads to higher filtration.

 

Option B. Increased Glomerular Hydrostatic Pressure: This also increases GFR because higher pressure in the glomerulus drives more filtrate into Bowman's capsule.

 

Option D. Decreased Glomerular Oncotic Pressure: This increases GFR because lower protein concentration in the glomerulus reduces the opposing force to filtration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure reduces net filtration pressure (NFP) and decreases glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Increased Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases filtration pressure and GFR.

choices.text: Loud S1 is a common finding
Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of chest pain and upper respiratory tract infection, seven days ago, presents with shortness of breath. She has BP of 100/60 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 110/min. Chest x-ray reviews an enlarged heart, which appears like a water bottle. Which of the following is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Loud S1 is a common finding

 

The patient is likely suffering from pericardial effusion, possibly progressing to cardiac tamponade, secondary to a recent viral infection. This is suggested by the history of an upper respiratory tract infection, the physical findings, and the characteristic "water bottle" appearance of the heart on the chest x-ray.

 

The incorrect statement is Loud S1 is a common finding. In fact, one of the hallmarks of cardiac tamponade is muffled or distant heart sounds due to the insulating effect of the pericardial fluid, as described in Beck's triad, which includes hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulsus Paradoxus is usually seen: This is true. Pulsus paradoxus is a significant drop in blood pressure during inspiration, common in cardiac tamponade.

 

Option B. Pericardiocentesis may be required: This is true. Pericardiocentesis is often necessary to remove the excess fluid and relieve pressure on the heart, especially if the patient is hemodynamically unstable.

 

Option D. Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse: This is true. In cardiac tamponade, the pressure from the pericardial fluid prevents the right atrium and right ventricle from expanding during diastole, leading to their collapse. Echocardiography will reveal this diastolic collapse, confirming cardiac tamponade.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac tamponade, muffled heart sounds are a key finding, not a loud S1.

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulants requires coagulation profile monitoring? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

 

Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, which requires routine coagulation profile monitoring. The standard test used for monitoring Lepirudin is the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). In cath labs, when administering in high doses need to be monitor with ACT (Activated Clotting Time) rather than aPTT.

 

This is necessary to ensure the correct therapeutic range is maintained and to avoid complications such as bleeding.

 

Note - There are four parenteral direct thrombin inhibitors: lepirudin, hirudin, bivalirudin, and argatroban.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). It has a predictable anticoagulant effect, and routine coagulation monitoring is generally not required under standard clinical circumstances. In special situations, monitoring can be done using anti-factor Xa levels.

 

Option C. Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux, like Enoxaparin, does not typically require routine coagulation monitoring due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics. In specific clinical scenarios, anti-factor Xa levels may be measured.

 

Option D. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor and is classified under direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs). Routine coagulation monitoring is not required due to its reliable and predictable effects. However, if monitoring is needed, aPTT can be used, though more specific tests like the dilute thrombin time (dTT) or the ecarin clotting time (ECT) are preferred for accurate measurement.

 

Note - There are four DOACs (Direct Oral Anticoagulants): Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor), Apixaban, Rivaroxaban and Edoxaban (all 3 are factor Xa inhibitor)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lepirudin, a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, requires routine coagulation profile monitoring using aPTT to ensure therapeutic efficacy and safety.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient weighing 60 kg is on mechanical ventilation for ARDS secondary to urosepsis. The respiratory parameters are as follows: tidal volume- 360 mL; frequency- 30 breaths/min; PEEP- 5 cm of H2O; and FiO2- 90%. The arterial blood gas findings are as follows: paO2- 50 mmHg; paCO2- 38 mmHg and pH- 7.38. What is the next step? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increase PEEP

 

Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) requires careful management of mechanical ventilation settings to optimize oxygenation while minimizing lung injury. The patient's current settings and blood gas findings suggest hypoxemia (paO2 of 50 mmHg) with an FiO2 of 90%. The goal in managing ARDS is to maintain adequate oxygenation (paO2 > 60 mmHg) while reducing the FiO2 to less than 60% to avoid oxygen toxicity.

 

Increasing PEEP is the best option to improve oxygenation. PEEP helps to keep alveoli open, improving gas exchange and oxygenation. By increasing PEEP, we can potentially increase the paO2 and eventually reduce the FiO2 to safer levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduce FiO2: Although reducing FiO2 is a long-term goal to prevent oxygen toxicity, it is not advisable to reduce it immediately because the patient is currently hypoxemic (paO2 of 50 mmHg).

 

Option B. Increase tidal volume: Not appropriate as it can increase the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury in ARDS patients. The current tidal volume is within the safe range (360 mL), which is appropriate for a 60 kg patient as it falls within the recommended range of 4-6 mL/kg for ARDS patients to prevent ventilator-induced lung injury.

 

Option C. Increase respiratory rate: Increasing the respiratory rate is not necessary in this situation as the paCO2 (38 mmHg) and pH (7.38) indicate normal ventilation and no significant respiratory acidosis (paCO2 is normal).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS management, if the patient remains hypoxemic despite a high FiO2, the next step is to increase the PEEP to improve oxygenation while maintaining lung-protective ventilation strategies.

choices.text: Presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies
Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies
Presence of Anti-HBc IgG antibodies

questions.text: Serologic findings of a patient with hepatitis are given below. HBsAg positive, Anti-HBc (total) positive, Anti-HDV (total) positive. Which of the following is most useful in diagnosing HDV co-infection over superinfection? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies

 

To differentiate between HDV co-infection and superinfection, it is essential to understand the nature of these infections:

 

  • Co-infection occurs when a patient acquires both acute HBV and acute HDV simultaneously. The presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies indicates a recent acute HBV infection, which is characteristic of co-infection.
  • Superinfection occurs when a patient with chronic HBV infection acquires an acute HDV infection. In this scenario, the patient has markers of chronic HBV (like Anti-HBc IgG antibodies) along with markers of acute HDV infection.

 

The Anti-HBc IgM antibodies are indicative of an acute HBV infection and are useful for diagnosing co-infection because they show that the HBV infection is recent, which aligns with the scenario of both HBV and HDV being acquired simultaneously.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High HDV viral load: This can be present in both co-infection and superinfection and does not specifically differentiate between the two.

 

Option C. Presence of IgM anti-HDV antibodies: These antibodies can be present in both co-infection and superinfection as they indicate an acute HDV infection. Therefore, they are not useful in differentiating between the two conditions.

 

Option D. Presence of Anti-HBc IgG antibodies: This indicates a past or chronic HBV infection. The presence of Anti-HBc IgG is more consistent with superinfection rather than co-infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Anti-HBc IgM antibodies is most useful in diagnosing HDV co-infection over superinfection because it indicates a recent acute HBV infection, which is characteristic of co-infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in UMN (Upper Motor Neuron) weakness? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyper-reflexia

 

Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) lesions are associated with a specific set of clinical features due to the disruption of the central motor pathways that originate in the cerebral cortex and descend through the brainstem and spinal cord to synapse on the lower motor neurons. The key features of UMN lesions include:

 

  • Hyper-reflexia: This is characterized by exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. The loss of inhibitory modulation from the cortex leads to an overactive reflex arc.
  • Spasticity: Increased muscle tone that is velocity-dependent, often seen in conjunction with hyper-reflexia.
  • Babinski sign: An abnormal reflex where the big toe extends upward when the sole of the foot is stimulated.
  • No significant muscle atrophy: While mild disuse atrophy can occur over time, it is not as pronounced as in lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions.
  • No fasciculations: Fasciculations, or spontaneous contractions of muscle fibers, are indicative of LMN lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrophy: Significant muscle atrophy is a hallmark of LMN lesions due to denervation of the muscles. It is not typically seen in UMN lesions except for mild disuse atrophy.

 

Option C. Rigidity: Rigidity is associated with extrapyramidal disorders, such as Parkinson's disease, and is characterized by increased muscle tone that is uniform and not velocity-dependent.

 

Option D. Fasciculations: Fasciculations are indicative of LMN lesions and result from spontaneous depolarization of lower motor neurons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hallmark feature of Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) weakness is hyper-reflexia, characterized by exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. This occurs due to the loss of inhibitory control from the brain on the reflex arcs in the spinal cord.

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect associated with the long-term use of intermittent teriparatide for the treatment of osteoporosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) used as an anabolic (bone-building) agent in the treatment of osteoporosis. It is administered via daily subcutaneous injections. While effective in increasing bone mass and reducing fracture risk, the long-term use of teriparatide has been associated with certain risks.

 

Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer that has been linked to the long-term use of teriparatide in animal studies. Specifically, when used for more than two years, there is evidence from these studies suggesting an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. This potential risk has led to a restriction on the duration of teriparatide therapy to a maximum of two years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteonecrosis of the jaw bone: This condition is a known adverse effect of bisphosphonates, not teriparatide. Bisphosphonates can lead to decreased blood flow to the jawbone, causing osteonecrosis, especially following dental procedures.

 

Option C. Subtrochanteric fracture (atypical femoral fracture): This type of fracture is also associated with long-term use of bisphosphonates, rather than teriparatide. Bisphosphonates may alter bone remodeling, leading to atypical fractures.

 

Option D. Loss of bone mass: Teriparatide is an anabolic agent that actually increases bone mass. Bisphosphonates also prevent bone mass loss by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption. Thus, loss of bone mass is not associated with either teriparatide or bisphosphonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The long-term use of teriparatide is associated with an increased risk of osteosarcoma, which is why its use is limited to a maximum of two years.

questions.text: Identify the crystal in a patient with urinary pH of 8.7: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple Phosphate

 

Normally, urinary pH typically ranges from 4.4 to 6.5, which is acidic.

 

Here, an alkaline urinary pH of 8.7 promotes the formation of certain types of crystals, particularly triple phosphate (struvite) and calcium phosphate crystals. The image provided shows typical "coffin-lid" shaped crystals, which are characteristic of triple phosphate (magnesium ammonium phosphate) or struvite crystals.

 

Triple Phosphate crystals are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive bacteria such as Proteus, Klebsiella, and Ureaplasma urealyticum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium Oxalate : These crystals typically form in acidic urine and have different shapes, such as envelope or dumbbell shapes.

 

Option C. Cystine : These crystals also form in acidic urine and have a distinctive hexagonal shape.

 

Option D. Uric Acid : These crystals form in acidic urine and appear as rhomboid or rosette shapes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triple phosphate (struvite) crystals are associated with alkaline urine and have a "coffin-lid" appearance. They are commonly seen in patients with urinary tract infections caused by urease-positive organisms.

choices.text: Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology
IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control
DC Cardioversion is required in all cases
Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis

questions.text: A 38-year-old man collapsed and was brought to the emergency. ECG was taken and a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AF) was made. Which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control

 

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm without distinct P waves on ECG, which confirms the diagnosis. Each of the provided options needs to be evaluated for accuracy.

 

IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control. This is the correct statement. IV Digoxin is used for rate control in AF, particularly in patients with heart failure.

 

If the patient is stable and not in acute heart failure, beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like verapamil or diltiazem are preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology: This statement is incorrect. Atrial fibrillation can occur in morphologically normal hearts. Studies indicate that 15-35% of AF cases can be seen in individuals with structurally normal hearts, although it is more common in those with conditions such as heart failure or left atrial enlargement.

 

Option C. DC Cardioversion is required in all cases: This statement is incorrect. DC cardioversion is reserved for unstable patients or for rhythm control in selected chronic cases. It is not required for all AF cases.

 

Option D. Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis: This statement is incorrect. While a pulse deficit (difference between heart rate and pulse rate) can suggest AF, it is not a reliable diagnostic criterion as it can be observed in other conditions such as frequent ventricular premature contractions, cardiac tamponade, and severe heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IV Digoxin can be effectively used for ventricular rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially in those with heart failure.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with left-sided hemiparesis. Damage to which part of the internal capsule leads to this presentation? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior limb

 

The internal capsule is a white matter structure in the brain that contains many important tracts, including those for motor and sensory functions. Damage to specific parts of the internal capsule can result in different clinical presentations based on the fibers that are affected.

 

Posterior limb is the part of the internal capsule that carries corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts, which are responsible for motor and sensory functions. Damage to the posterior limb can result in contralateral hemiparesis (weakness on the opposite side of the body). Therefore, a lesion in the posterior limb of the right internal capsule would lead to left-sided hemiparesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retrolentiform: This part of the internal capsule contains optic radiations, which are involved in visual processing. Damage here would lead to visual deficits rather than motor or sensory deficits.

 

Option B. Sublentiform: This part carries auditory radiations and is involved in hearing. Damage to this part would result in auditory deficits, not motor weakness.

 

Option C. Anterior limb: This part of the internal capsule contains frontopontine fibers and thalamocortical radiations, which are involved in cognitive and executive functions. Damage here might affect cognition but not typically result in hemiparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the posterior limb of the internal capsule can lead to contralateral hemiparesis due to the involvement of motor and sensory pathways.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with heart failure and poorly controlled type 2 diabetes (HbA1c of 7.8%) presents with progressive dyspnea. Which is the preferred antidiabetic drug? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

Dapagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT2) inhibitor that has shown significant benefits in patients with heart failure, particularly heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). SGLT2 inhibitors, including dapagliflozin and empagliflozin, have been demonstrated to improve survival, reduce heart failure hospitalizations, and delay the progression of heart failure. These benefits make SGLT2 inhibitors the preferred choice for patients with both type 2 diabetes and heart failure.

 

Four Pillars in the Management of HFrEF (Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction):

 

  1. ARNIs and ACE Inhibitors/ARBs:
    • ARNIs (e.g., Sacubitril/Valsartan) are preferred.
    • ACE Inhibitors/ARBs are also used.
  2. Beta Blockers:
    • Metoprolol
    • Bisoprolol
    • Carvedilol
  3. MRAs (Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists):
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone
  4. SGLT2 Inhibitors:
    • Empagliflozin
    • Dapagliflozin

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glimepiride: This is a sulfonylurea that primarily helps in lowering blood glucose by stimulating insulin secretion. It does not provide the cardiovascular benefits seen with SGLT2 inhibitors and can increase the risk of hypoglycemia.

 

Option C. Metformin: While metformin is a first-line therapy for type 2 diabetes and has some cardiovascular benefits, it is not specifically indicated for improving heart failure outcomes.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: This is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor used to manage blood glucose levels. It does not provide the same level of heart failure benefit as SGLT2 inhibitors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with type 2 diabetes and heart failure, SGLT2 inhibitors like dapagliflozin are the preferred antidiabetic medications due to their proven benefits in reducing heart failure progression, hospitalizations, and mortality.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroid eye disease

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease, also known as Graves' ophthalmopathy. This condition is associated with autoimmune thyroid disease, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the tissues around the eyes, leading to inflammation and swelling. This results in the characteristic bulging of the eyes, known as proptosis or exophthalmos.

 

Thyroid eye disease is particularly common in middle-aged individuals and can cause both unilateral (one eye) and bilateral (both eyes) proptosis. The pathophysiology involves the expansion of the extraocular muscles and increased orbital fat, leading to the protrusion of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft tissue tumour in orbit: While soft tissue tumors in the orbit can cause proptosis, they are not the most common cause in middle-aged individuals. These tumors can be benign or malignant and require imaging studies for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Optic nerve meningioma: This type of tumor is associated with neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and can lead to proptosis. However, it is less common compared to thyroid eye disease.

 

Option D. Cavernous hemangioma: Although cavernous hemangioma is the most common orbital tumor in adults, it is not the most common cause of proptosis. These benign vascular tumors can cause proptosis if they become large enough to displace the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of proptosis in a middle-aged person is thyroid eye disease (Graves' ophthalmopathy).

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. The diagnostic criteria for DKA typically include:

 

  • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose levels greater than 250 mg/dL.
  • Ketosis: Presence of ketones in the blood or urine.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Indicated by an arterial pH of less than 7.3, a serum bicarbonate level of less than 15-18 mEq/L, and an anion gap greater than 12.

 

S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L is not a diagnostic criterion for DKA. Although potassium imbalance is common in DKA due to shifts between the intracellular and extracellular compartments, serum potassium levels are not used as a diagnostic criterion. Potassium levels can vary and might be normal, elevated, or decreased, depending on the stage of DKA and the treatment administered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S. glucose > 250 mg/dL: This is a diagnostic criterion for DKA as it confirms the presence of significant hyperglycemia.

 

Option B. Arterial pH < 7.3: This indicates metabolic acidosis, which is a key component of DKA.

 

Option C. Anion gap > 12: An increased anion gap signifies high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), which is typical in DKA due to the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for DKA include hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Potassium levels, while important to monitor and manage in DKA, are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following will not be measured to diagnose metabolic syndrome? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hip circumference


Metabolic syndrome criteria include: HDL levels, Blood glucose, Blood pressure and Waist circumference (NOT hip circumference)

 

Waist circumference - more than 102 centimeter in males or more than 88 centimeter in females is one of the important criteria for metabolic syndrome. Central obesity is a criterion for metabolic syndrome.

 

Other Options:


Option A. HDL levels: Low HDL levels (<40 mg/dL in males, <50 mg/dL in females) are a criterion for metabolic syndrome.

High triglyceride levels (>150 mg/dL) are a criterion for metabolic syndrome.


Option C. Blood glucose: Impaired glucose tolerance or type 2 diabetes is a criterion for metabolic syndrome.

 

Option D. Blood pressure: BP >140/90 mmHg or being hypertensive is a criterion for metabolic syndrome.

 

Note - To diagnose metabolic syndrome, the presence of at least three of these criteria is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hip circumference is not used in the diagnosis of metabolic syndrome; instead, waist circumference is measured.

choices.text: MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct

questions.text: Thrombolysis can be considered in all of these conditions, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg

 

Blood pressure of > 185/110 mmHg: This is a contraindication for thrombolysis. Elevated blood pressure increases the risk of hemorrhagic complications during thrombolysis. Therefore, blood pressure must be controlled to below 185/110 mmHg before initiating thrombolytic therapy.

 

Thrombolysis is a treatment used to dissolve blood clots in certain types of stroke patients. It is most effective when administered within a specific time window from the onset of symptoms and under certain conditions to ensure patient safety and efficacy of the treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI showing < 1/3rd of MCA territorial infarct: This indicates that the infarct size is within a range that is generally considered safe for thrombolysis. More extensive infarcts (> 1/3rd of the middle cerebral artery territory) are a contraindication due to the higher risk of hemorrhagic transformation.

 

Option C. Ischemia < 2 hours and D. Onset of symptoms < 4 hours: Both of these options fall within the critical time window for thrombolysis, which is generally considered up to 4.5 hours from symptom onset. Treatment within this time frame can significantly improve outcomes in stroke patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thrombolysis is contraindicated in patients with blood pressure higher than 185/110 mmHg at the time of treatment.

choices.text: TPE removes the von Willebrand factor
TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

questions.text: Total plasma exchange is done in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. How does TPE help in the management of TTP? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases ADAMTS protease activity

 

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is caused by a deficiency of ADAMTS13, usually due to autoantibodies. Total plasma exchange (TPE) removes these autoantibodies, thereby increasing ADAMTS13 protease activity and preventing the accumulation of large von Willebrand factor multimers. This results in platelet trapping. Classic clinical picture includes:

 

  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA)
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • End-organ damage (neurological injury)
  • Fever

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. TPE removes the von Willebrand factor: Incorrect; the goal is to remove autoantibodies.
 

Option B. TPE removes the antiplatelet antibodies: Incorrect; TTP involves anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies.
 

Option C. TPE replenishes the coagulation factors: Incorrect; TTP is not primarily a coagulation factor deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TPE in TTP primarily removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies, increasing ADAMTS13 activity and reducing microthrombi formation.

questions.text: A female presented with excessive daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory for one year. On examination the BMI was 43 kg/m² and BP was 170/98 mmHg. ABG was done in awake state and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis? PaO2: 70 mmHg PaCO2: 53 mmHg HCO3: 33 mmHg. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), also known as Pickwickian syndrome, is characterized by obesity (BMI >30 kg/m²), hypoventilation (PaCO2 >45 mmHg), and lack of significant underlying lung disease. The ABG findings showing hypercapnia (high PaCO2) and hypoxemia (low PaO2) in the awake state are indicative of OHS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Obstructive sleep apnea: Occurs during sleep, not necessarily presenting with hypercapnia in the awake state.
 

Option C. Central sleep apnea: Characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep without the obesity-related hypoventilation.
 

Option D. Narcolepsy: Does not typically present with ABG abnormalities or obesity hypoventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome involves obesity, chronic hypercapnia, and hypoxemia, primarily in the awake state.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with weight gain, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae, and easy bruising. What is the likely underlying condition? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypercortisolism

 

Hypercortisolism, also known as Cushing's syndrome, is characterized by an excess of cortisol in the body. The clinical features of Cushing's syndrome include weight gain, particularly in the face, neck, and trunk, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae (stretch marks), and easy bruising. These symptoms are a result of the catabolic effects of cortisol on various tissues.

 

  • Weight Gain: Cortisol promotes the deposition of fat in specific areas, leading to central obesity.
  • Proximal Muscle Weakness: Cortisol has catabolic effects on muscle tissue, leading to muscle wasting and weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles.
  • Purple Striae: Cortisol weakens the skin by breaking down collagen, leading to the formation of purple striae.
  • Easy Bruising: Cortisol reduces the ability of blood vessels to repair themselves, causing increased bruising.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: This condition involves an excess of thyroid hormones, leading to symptoms such as weight loss, increased appetite, heat intolerance, and hyperactivity. It does not typically cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option C. Hyperparathyroidism: This condition involves an excess of parathyroid hormone, leading to hypercalcemia, bone pain, kidney stones, and abdominal pain. It does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Option D. Hyperaldosteronism: This condition involves an excess of aldosterone, leading to hypertension and hypokalemia. It does not cause the symptoms described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's syndrome, or hypercortisolism, is characterized by weight gain, proximal muscle weakness, purple striae, and easy bruising due to the catabolic effects of excess cortisol.

questions.text: Identify the sign? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Babinski sign


The Babinski sign is a reflex response where the big toe extends upward and the other toes fan out upon stimulation of the sole. This indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ankle jerk: Reflex action at the ankle joint.
 

Option C. Jendrassik: Maneuver to enhance reflexes.
 

Option D. Normal plantar response: Flexion of all toes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Babinski sign indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

choices.text: Chest compression to Rescue breath ratio is 30:2

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding High-Quality CPR?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Depth of compression must be 3-4cm

 

The statement "Depth of compression must be 3-4cm" is incorrect for high-quality CPR. The correct depth of chest compression for adults is approximately 5 centimeters (or 2 inches). This depth ensures adequate blood flow during cardiopulmonary resuscitation. The 3-4cm depth mentioned in the option is insufficient for effective CPR in adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest compressions at 100-120/min: This is correct. The recommended rate for chest compressions during CPR is 100-120 compressions per minute. This rate optimizes blood flow during resuscitation efforts.

 

Option B. Allow adequate chest recoil: This statement is correct. Allowing full chest recoil between compressions is crucial for effective CPR. It enables proper diastolic filling of the heart, improving overall circulation.

 

Option C. Chest compression to Rescue breath ratio is 30:2: This is also correct. For adult CPR without an advanced airway, the standard ratio is 30 chest compressions followed by 2 rescue breaths.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In high-quality CPR for adults, the correct depth of chest compressions is approximately 5 centimeters (2 inches), not 3-4cm as stated in the incorrect option.

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Hypokalemia

2.Hypochloremia

3.Metabolic alkalosis

4.Respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea can lead to multiple metabolic abnormalities: Hypokalemia, Hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

 

1. Hypokalemia: Loss of potassium through vomiting and diarrhea.

 

2. Hypochloremia: Loss of chloride.

 

3. Metabolic alkalosis: Loss of gastric acids.

 

These changes are due to the loss of electrolytes and fluids.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Respiratory alkalosis involves hyperventilation and a decrease in carbon dioxide, which is unrelated to the described condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea typically cause hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Which one is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Purulent conjunctivitis

 

Purulent conjunctivitis is not a criterion for Kawasaki disease. Instead, the conjunctivitis seen in Kawasaki disease is non-purulent and sterile, meaning it does not produce pus, and cultures are negative.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute, self-limited vasculitis that predominantly affects children. The diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease include the presence of fever for at least five days, along with at least four of the following five clinical features:

 

  1. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival injection (conjunctivitis): This is a common feature in Kawasaki disease, but it is non-purulent (does not produce pus).
  2. Changes in the lips and oral cavity: This includes strawberry tongue (a red, bumpy tongue), erythema, and cracking of the lips.
  3. Polymorphous rash: A rash of various forms can be present.
  4. Cervical lymphadenopathy: Typically unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm in diameter.
  5. Changes in the extremities: This includes erythema of the palms and soles, edema of the hands and feet, and later desquamation (peeling) of the skin.

 

TOC - IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin) ± Aspirin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rash: A polymorphous rash is one of the key diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Option C. Lymphadenopathy: Cervical lymphadenopathy is another diagnostic criterion, usually unilateral and larger than 1.5 cm.

 

Option D. Strawberry tongue: Changes in the lips and oral cavity, including strawberry tongue, are diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is diagnosed based on a set of clinical criteria, including non-purulent conjunctivitis, rash, lymphadenopathy, and changes in the oral cavity such as strawberry tongue. Purulent conjunctivitis is not a feature of Kawasaki disease.

choices.text: Occur in the early 20s, rare after 40
More common in males than females
HLA B27 is positive in >90%
MRI shows non-erosive joint widening

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding Ankylosing Spondylitis are true except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MRI shows non-erosive joint widening

 

MRI shows non-erosive joint widening: This is false. In ankylosing spondylitis, MRI typically shows evidence of erosions, joint narrowing, and inflammatory changes in the sacroiliac joints and spine. The disease can lead to ankylosis (fusion of the spine), syndesmophytes, and erosive arthropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints. The correct statements regarding AS are:

 

Option A. Occur in the early 20s, rare after 40: Ankylosing spondylitis typically presents in young adults, often in their 20s, and is uncommon after the age of 40.

 

Option B. More common in males than females: AS is more prevalent in males, with a male-to-female ratio of approximately 3:1.

 

Option C. HLA B27 is positive in >90%: Over 90% of patients with AS test positive for the HLA-B27 gene, which is a significant marker for the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI findings in ankylosing spondylitis typically show erosive changes and joint narrowing, not non-erosive joint widening.

questions.text:
A female with nephrotic syndrome underwent a renal biopsy. Which of the following statements is correct? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy
  2. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy
  3. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma
  4. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo abdominal fat pad biopsy instead of renal biopsy
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2,3,4

 

Following a renal biopsy, it is crucial to monitor the patient for potential complications, including bleeding and hematoma formation.

 

2. Observation post-biopsy: Patients should be observed for 24 hours following a renal biopsy to monitor for complications such as bleeding or infection.

 

3. Dark red clots in urine: Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy can indicate a hematoma. This is a potential complication that needs to be monitored.

 

4. Abdominal fat pad biopsy: Patients with systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement can undergo an abdominal fat pad biopsy as an alternative to a renal biopsy. This method can help diagnose systemic amyloidosis with less risk compared to a renal biopsy.

 

Other Option:

 

1. FSGS cannot be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy: This statement is incorrect. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can indeed be diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy. The biopsy helps in identifying the characteristic histological changes associated with FSGS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post-biopsy observation, recognition of biopsy-related complications, and alternative biopsy methods for systemic amyloidosis are essential in nephrotic syndrome management.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was admitted to the hospital after three days of abdominal pain and vomiting. His laboratory reports revealed a potassium value of 3.2 mEq/L. All of the following can be seen except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cerebral edema

 

The patient has hypokalemia, indicated by a potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L.

 

This is not seen with Cerebral edema, which is typically associated with hyponatremia (low sodium levels) rather than hypokalemia. Hyponatremia can lead to an osmotic imbalance, causing water to move into brain cells and resulting in cerebral edema. This is not a recognized complication of hypokalemia.

 

Other options:

 

Hypokalemia can lead to several clinical manifestations:

 

Option A. Ventricular tachycardia: Hypokalemia can cause ventricular arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia, due to its effect on cardiac electrical activity. Potassium is crucial for maintaining normal heart rhythm, and its deficiency can lead to dangerous arrhythmias.

 

Option B. Quadriparesis: Hypokalemia can cause muscle weakness and paralysis, including quadriparesis. It affects muscle function because potassium is essential for normal muscle cell function and nerve transmission. Severe hypokalemia can mimic conditions like Guillain-Barré syndrome.

 

Option C. Diabetes insipidus: Hypokalemia can cause nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This condition occurs due to a defect in the kidney's ability to respond to antidiuretic hormone (ADH), leading to excessive urination and thirst. Hypokalemia impairs the kidney's concentrating ability, contributing to this disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cerebral edema is not associated with hypokalemia; it is a complication of hyponatremia. Hypokalemia can cause ventricular arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: A patient in emergency has the following lab parameters: creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. The chest x-ray is shown below. In gram staining and culture only, rhinovirus was isolated. The patient is shifted to ICU. What is the treatment of choice in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ceftriaxone plus azithromycin

 

The patient is diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and has been shifted to the ICU. The treatment of choice for ICU-admitted patients with CAP includes a beta-lactam antibiotic like beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitor (BL/BLI) combination like amoxicillin-clavulanic acid or piperacillin-tazobactam, or a third-generation cephalosporin like ceftriaxone combined with azithromycin or a respiratory fluoroquinolone such as levofloxacin or moxifloxacin should be administered.

 

Ceftriaxone are used to cover typical bacteria, while azithromycin covers atypical bacteria and provides additional anti-inflammatory properties.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Azithromycin: Insufficient as monotherapy in ICU settings.
 

Option C. Amoxicillin plus clavulanic acid: Lacks coverage for atypical pathogens alone.
 

Option D. Piperacillin Tazobactam plus ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is not a respiratory fluoroquinolone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of a beta-lactam antibiotic and azithromycin is the treatment of choice for ICU-admitted patients with community-acquired pneumonia.

choices.text: Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA)
High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)
Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department presenting with symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea, and tachycardia. Laboratory results are as follows: pH: 7.34, Sodium: 135 mmol/L, Potassium: 5 mmol/L, Bicarbonate: 12 mmol/L, Chloride: 92 mmol/L, RBS: 450 mg/dL. Given these laboratory findings, which of the following statements best describes the patient's acid-base status? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (HAGMA)

 

The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings suggest diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a condition commonly seen in diabetes patients with high blood sugar levels (RBS: 450 mg/dL). The symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, tachypnea (rapid breathing), and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) are characteristic of DKA.

 

The laboratory values indicate a metabolic acidosis:

 

  • pH of 7.34: Slightly acidic, indicating acidosis.
  • Bicarbonate of 12 mmol/L: Low, consistent with metabolic acidosis.
  • Chloride of 92 mmol/L: Lower than normal.

 

To determine the type of metabolic acidosis, we calculate the anion gap:

 

 

An anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L indicates a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA). In this case, the anion gap is 31, confirming HAGMA. 

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis is typically associated with conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, renal failure, and ingestion of toxins.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Non-Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (NAGMA): This occurs when the anion gap is normal (less than 12 mmol/L). Conditions that cause NAGMA include diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis. This does not match the patient's high anion gap.

 

Option C. Compensated Metabolic Alkalosis: This condition involves an elevated pH with high bicarbonate levels. The patient’s pH is acidic, not alkalotic, and bicarbonate is low.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis: Characterized by a primary increase in carbon dioxide (CO2) levels leading to a low pH. The patient’s primary disturbance is metabolic, not respiratory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) is characterized by an anion gap greater than 12 mmol/L, indicating an accumulation of unmeasured anions. This condition is often seen in diabetic ketoacidosis, which presents with elevated blood glucose levels and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following connective tissue degradation disorder is associated with aortic aneurysm? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marfan's Syndrome

 

Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder that affects the body's connective tissues, which provide structural support to various organs and tissues. It is particularly associated with cardiovascular complications, including aortic aneurysms and dissections. This is due to the weakening of the aortic wall caused by defective fibrillin-1, a glycoprotein essential for the elasticity and strength of the connective tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome: While Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) can lead to vascular complications, including aortic aneurysms, it is specifically the vascular type (Type IV) of EDS that is associated with these issues. However, Marfan's Syndrome is more commonly linked to aortic aneurysms.

 

Option C. Atherosclerosis: Atherosclerosis is a condition characterized by the build-up of plaque within the arterial walls, leading to narrowing and hardening of the arteries. It is a risk factor for abdominal aortic aneurysm but is not classified as a connective tissue disorder.

 

Option D. Scurvy: Scurvy is caused by a deficiency in vitamin C, leading to defective collagen synthesis. While it results in symptoms like mucosal bleeding and poor wound healing, it is not associated with aortic aneurysms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marfan's Syndrome is a connective tissue disorder closely associated with the development of aortic aneurysms due to the defective fibrillin-1 protein affecting the structural integrity of the aortic wall.

questions.text: All of the following are functions of the superior oblique except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adduction

 

Explanation:

 

Adduction is not a function of the superior oblique muscle. Adduction involves moving the eyeball towards the midline (towards the nose), and this movement is primarily mediated by the medial rectus muscle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Abduction: The superior oblique muscle helps in the lateral movement of the eyeball, meaning it moves the eye away from the midline (abduction).

 

Option C. Depression: When the eye is adducted (turned towards the nose), the superior oblique muscle helps to depress the eyeball, moving it downward.

 

Option D. Intorsion: This is the primary function of the superior oblique muscle. Intorsion involves the rotation of the top of the eyeball towards the nose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The superior oblique muscle is one of the extraocular muscles and is innervated by the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV). The primary functions of the superior oblique muscle can be remembered using the mnemonic "SO-LID":

 

  • Superior Oblique
  • Lateral movement (Abduction)
  • Intorsion
  • Depression

questions.text: Which of the following in IgA vasculitis warrants the use of corticosteroids? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GI bleeding

 

IgA vasculitis, also known as Henoch-Schönlein purpura, typically presents with symptoms such as arthritis, abdominal pain, and skin rash. These symptoms are often managed with supportive care and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). However, the use of corticosteroids is reserved for more severe manifestations of the disease.

 

GI bleeding: In cases where IgA vasculitis leads to gastrointestinal bleeding, corticosteroids are warranted. This is because GI bleeding indicates a severe form of the disease involving the gastrointestinal tract, which requires more aggressive treatment to reduce inflammation and prevent further complications.

 

Other Options:
